revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} '''Gary Lloyd''' (born 1965) is a Canadian-born British composer and producer. He has composed music for productions in theatre, contemporary dance, television drama and documentary, film, art installation, ''[[son et lumière (show)|son et lumiere]]'', narrative/music works, and orchestral concert performances. He also works as a record producer, and lectures on aspects of music. He is a graduate of the University of Chester where he studied mathematics, fine art and history of art, and psychology.
He lives in [[Chester]] with his partner the dancer and choreographer Bettina Carpi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.candoco.co.uk/about-us/people/candoco-artists/bettina-carpi/|title=Bettina Carpi|work=''Candoco.co.uk''|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sky.com/tv/show/metamorphosis/article/about|title=A Dance Metamorphosis|work=Find and Watch|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref>
==Past works== Past works include the theatrical scores for [[Jean Paul Sartre]]'s '[[Huis Clos]]' (''No Way Out'') (2001)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uktw.co.uk/archive/Tour/Play/No-Way-Out-Huis-Clos/T468304778/|title=Tour archive for No Way Out (Huis Clos) (Play). 14 March 2001 – 12 April 2001 [TOUR]|work=''Uktw.co.uk''|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> and [[Arthur Kopit]]'s ''Road To Nirvana'' (2006)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecnj.com/old6april-5May06/review/041306/feat041306_01.html|title=Camden New Journal – FEATURE|work=''Thecnj.com''|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> both directed by actor and director [[Colin McFarlane]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.colinmcfarlane.tv/films/|title=Films|work=Colinmcfarlane.tv|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> soundtracks for the ''Tshukudu'' series of wildlife documentaries by ''Marianne Wilding'' (1998–2005), music for the contemporary dance piece ''Nocturne''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marcbrew.com/marc-brew-company/productions/nocturne/|title=Nocturne|work=Marc Brew}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iain-banks.net/2009/06/26/pure-poetry-as-iain-banks-adds-audio-to-mark-brews-nocturne/|title=Iain [M] Banks|work=Iain-banks.net}}</ref> choreographed by [[Marc Brew]] (2009 and onwards including a performance at [[Sadler's Wells]] in 2014),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sadlerswells.com/whats-on/2014/equaldance-statement-pieces/|title=Sadler's Wells Theatre – =dance Statement Pieces|work=''Sadlerswells.com''}}</ref> music for installations with the artist Michelle Molyneux (2007),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artinliverpool.com/?p=3948|title=Artinliverpool.com – Michelle Molyneux at Williamson – Review|work=''Artinliverpool.com''}}</ref> and music for the contemporary dance piece ''Track'' choreographed by ''Paula Hampson'' (1997–1998).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merseyworld.com/hermeus/paula.htm|title=hermeus – paula hampson|work=''Merseyworld.com''}}</ref> Earlier works include the soundtrack for the stage version of [[Neil Gaiman]] and [[Dave McKean]]'s '[[Violent Cases]]' directed by ''Eric Jarvis'' (1988).
He created two narrative/music pieces that were released on CD: the first based on ''[[The Bridge (novel)|The Bridge]]'' (1996)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://explore.bl.uk/primo_library/libweb/action/search.do?dscnt=0&frbg=&scp.scps=scope%3A%28BLCONTENT%29&tab=local_tab&dstmp=1433188365445&srt=rank&ct=search&mode=Basic&vl(488279563UI0)=any&dum=true&tb=t&indx=1&vl(freeText0)=gary%20lloyd%20iain%20banks&vid=BLVU1&fn=search|title=|work=Bl.uk}}</ref> by [[Iain Banks]] and the second ''[[Brought to Light]]'' (1998)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://explore.bl.uk/primo_library/libweb/action/search.do?dscnt=0&frbg=&scp.scps=scope%3A%28BLCONTENT%29&tab=local_tab&dstmp=1433188976276&srt=rank&ct=search&mode=Basic&vl(488279563UI0)=any&dum=true&tb=t&indx=1&vl(freeText0)=gary%20lloyd%20alan%20moore&vid=BLVU1&fn=search|title=|work=Bl.uk}}</ref> based on the comic book written by [[Alan Moore]]. Lloyd worked in collaboration with the novelists on each and Banks and Moore each voiced their respective works. Banks and Lloyd were frequent collaborators<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/1999/aug/07/fiction.iainbanks|title=Doing the Business|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> and they co-composed a collection of songs as an album in tribute to the fictional band from Banks's novel ''[[Espedair Street]]'' – a tribute to a band that never existed – first mooted in 1999 by Lloyd<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/1999/jul/22/features11.g21|title=Work in progress|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> and also discussed in Banks's only non-fiction book ''[[Raw Spirit]]''. This collaborative project between Banks and Lloyd was restarted in 2005 and although the groundwork of the project was completed to date it remains unreleased. Lloyd spoke at length about his work with Banks at the 2014 Huddersfield Literature Festival<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.litfest.org.uk/sites/default/files/docs/HUDDFESTIVAL_2014_WEB.pdf |format=PDF |title=Huddersfield Literature Festival 2014 Brochure |publisher=Litfest.org |accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> and about his work with Moore at the 2010 Magus Conference<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nectar.northampton.ac.uk/3798/1/Wiseman-Trowse20113798.pdf |format=PDF |title=Studies in Comics : Alan Moore Themed Issue 2:1 |publisher=Nectar.northampton.ac.uk |accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> at the [[University of Northampton]].
In 2014 Lloyd composed ''The Bridge Redux (In Memoriam Iain Banks)''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldconphilharmonicorchestra.com/about/|title=About – Worldcon Philharmonic Orchestra|work=''worldconphilharmonicorchestra.com''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldconphilharmonicorchestra.com/video/|title=Videos Archive – Worldcon Philharmonic Orchestra|work=''worldconphilharmonicorchestra.com''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.loncon3.org/documents/WORLDCON-PHILHARMONIC-ORCHESTRA-programme-guide-v09.pdf |format=PDF |title=Worldcon Philharmonic Orchestra : Programme |publisher=Loncon3.org |accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> which was performed by the [[Worldcon Philharmonic Orchestra]] and conducted by [[Keith Slade]] at [[Loncon 3]], the [[72nd World Science Fiction Convention]], at the [[ExCeL London]] to an audience of four thousand. He introduced the piece with a personal tribute to Banks who was guest of honour.
==Company Carpi== Company Carpi is the name of the dance theatre company established by Bettina Carpi and Gary Lloyd. The company aim is to produce works which "combines music & dance with other art forms to present imaginative live performance pieces which address societal topics".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.https://www.companycarpi.com/about}}</ref>
Company Carpi's first fully funded (by Arts Council England and other sources) production was ''The Mirror Of Love'' based on the prose-poem by [[Alan Moore]] which was first performed in 2017. The company followed this in 2018 with ''Knots'' based on the book by revolutionary psychiatrist R.D. Laing. ==Works in progress== Lloyd is currently working with Bettina Carpi on a dance theatre adaptation<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mary-talbot.co.uk/dancetheatre-adaptation-of-dotter-of-her-fathers-eyes/|title=Dance/theatre adaptation of Dotter of her Father's Eyes|work=Mary Talbot's Website}}</ref> of [[Mary M. Talbot|Mary Talbot]] and [[Bryan Talbot]]'s [[Costa Award]]-winning graphic novel '[[Dotter of her Father's Eyes]]'. Lloyd, Carpi, the Talbots, and dancer Christopher Owen presented work in progress at the Huddersfield Literature Festival 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.litfest.org.uk/?q=diary#Storytelling%20&%20Adaptation|title=Huddersfield Literature Festival 2015|publisher=Litfest.org|accessdate=2 June 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510155318/http://www.litfest.org.uk/?q=diary#Storytelling%20&%20Adaptation |archivedate=10 May 2015}}</ref> The eventual form of the production will be opera with dance.
Lloyd is also currently in the preparatory stages of composing his first orchestral symphony.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lloyd, Gary}} [[Category:British composers]] [[Category:Contemporary dance]] [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox artwork | title = Heart Beacon | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | artist = {{Flatlist| * Blessing Hancock * Joe O'Connell}} | catalogue = | year = {{start date|2013}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | type = Sculpture | material = {{Flatlist| * [[Stainless steel]] * acrylic panels * electrical components }} | subject = | height_metric = <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | condition = | city = [[Portland, Oregon]], United States | museum = | accession = | coordinates = {{coord|45.49442|-122.56078|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = Portland | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Portland, Oregon | pushpin_label_position = | owner = | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | website = <!-- Official webpage/site only: {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''''Heart Beacon''''' is an outdoor 2013 sculpture by American artists Blessing Hancock and Joe O'Connell, installed at the Bureau of Emergency Management's Emergency Coordination Center in [[Portland, Oregon]], United States.
==Description== ''Heart Beacon'', installed at the Emergency Coordination Center (3732 Southeast 99th Avenue or 9911 Southeast Bush Street) in Portland's [[Powellhurst-Gilbert, Portland, Oregon|Powellhurst-Gilbert]] neighborhood, has been described as a "pulsing blue egg"; the artists have called it an "interactive enclosure of light, color and sound that senses and artistically displays the heartbeat of visitors".<ref name=RACC>{{cite web|title=Public Art Search: Heart Beacon|url=http://racc.org/public-art/search/?recid=3266.26|publisher=[[Regional Arts & Culture Council]]|accessdate=September 4, 2015}}</ref><ref name=WW>{{cite news|title=Murmurs: News That Doesn't Know When to Quit.|url=http://www.wweek.com/portland/article-21137-murmurs_news_that_doesnt_know_when_to_quit.html|accessdate=September 4, 2015|work=[[Willamette Week]]|date=September 11, 2013}}</ref> It is made of [[stainless steel]], acrylic panels, and electrical components, and measures 18' 1 7/8" x 10' 5". The sculpture cost $220,333 and was funded by the city's Percent for Art program.<ref name=RACC/><ref name=WW/> According to the [[Regional Arts & Culture Council]], which administers the work, ''Heart Beacon'' "takes the literal and metamorphic 'pulse'" of Portland's community and serves as a "symbol of hope and a potent reminder of the resilience of the individual taking inspiration from the life-saving mission" of the center. <ref name=RACC/>
==See also== * [[2013 in art]] * [[Interactive art]] * [[List of public art in Portland, Oregon]] * [[Sound sculpture]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:2013 establishments in Portland, Oregon]] [[Category:2013 sculptures]] [[Category:Interactive art]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Portland, Oregon]] [[Category:Powellhurst-Gilbert, Portland, Oregon]] [[Category:Sound sculptures]] [[Category:Stainless steel sculptures in Oregon]]

{{multiple issues| {{sources|date=July 2015}} {{missing information|the film's release, initial reception, and controversy|date=July 2015}} }}
{{Infobox film | name = Jigoku | image = Jigokuposter.jpg | alt = | caption = | film name = <!-- {{Infobox name module|language|title}} or {{Infobox name module|title}} --> | director = [[Nobuo Nakagawa]] | producer = Mitsugu Okura{{sfn|Galbraith IV|1996|p=359}} | writer = | screenplay = {{plainlist|*Nobuo Nakagawa *Ichirō Miyagawa{{sfn|Galbraith IV|1996|p=359}}}} | story = | based on = <!-- {{Based on|title of the original work|writer of the original work}} --> | starring = Utako Mitsuya | music = Chumei Watanabe<ref name="criterion">{{cite web|url=https://www.criterion.com/films/797-jigoku|publisher=[[Criterion Collection]]|title=Jigoku|accessdate=November 10, 2016}}</ref> | cinematography = Mamoru Morita{{sfn|Galbraith IV|1996|p=359}} | editing = [[Toshio Goto]]<ref name="criterion" /> | studio = [[Shintoho]]{{sfn|Galbraith IV|1996|p=359}} | distributor = <!-- or: | distributors = --> | released = {{Film date|df=yes|1960|07|30|Japan}} | runtime = 100 minutes{{sfn|Galbraith IV|1996|p=359}} | country = Japan{{sfn|Galbraith IV|1996|p=359}} | language = | budget = | gross = }}
{{nihongo|'''''Jigoku'''''|地獄||"Hell"}}, also titled '''''The Sinners of Hell''''', is a [[1960 in film|1960]] Shintoho [[J-Horror|Japanese horror film]], directed by [[Nobuo Nakagawa]] and starring [[Utako Mitsuya]] and [[Shigeru Amachi]]. The 1960 film was advertised as adult entertainment.<ref>Galbraith,Stuart (1994). ''Japanese Fantasy, Science Fiction and Horror Films''. McFarland and Co., Inc.</ref> ''Jigoku'' is notable for separating itself from other [[J-horror|Japanese horror]] films of the era such as ''[[Kwaidan (film)|Kwaidan]]'' or ''[[Onibaba (film)|Onibaba]]'' due to its graphic imagery of torment in Hell.<ref>Galbraith,Stuart (1994). ''Japanese Fantasy, Science Fiction and Horror Films''. McFarland and Co., Inc.</ref> It has gained a [[cult film]] status. Shintoho declared bankruptcy in 1961, its last production being ''Jigoku''.{{sfn|Galbraith IV|1994|p=317}}
''Jigoku'' was re-made in 1969 by Toho Films (as ''[[Portrait of Hell]]'')<ref>Galbraith,Stuart (1994)</ref>, again in 1979 by Toei Films (as simply ''Jigoku''), and later re-made once again in 1999 by Toei under the title of ''[[Jigoku: Japanese Hell]]'', directed by [[Teruo Ishii]].<ref>Galbraith,Stuart (1994). ''Japanese Fantasy, Science Fiction and Horror Films''. McFarland and Co., Inc.</ref>
==Plot== A young Tokyo theology student, Shirō (Shigeru Amachi), is set to marry his girlfriend, Yukiko (Utako Mitsuya), the daughter of his professor, Mr. Yajima. After announcing the engagement, Shirō's dark and unsettling colleague, Tamura (Yôichi Numata), drives Shirō home, suggesting that Shirō had been sleeping with Yukiko for some time. Taking a side street at Shirō's request, Tamura hits and kills drunken yakuza gang leader, Kyōichi. Though Shirō wants to stop, Tamura keeps driving, stating that it does not concern him and that ultimately, the murder is Shirō's fault for asking him to drive down the street. Unbeknown to either of them, Kyōichi's mother (Kiyoko Tsuji) witnessed everything and resolves to find and kill them.
Though Tamura feels no guilt for the murder, Shirō does and attempts to go to the police. After telling Yukiko of what happened, Shirō insists that they take a taxi cab to the police station, despite Yukiko's pleas to walk instead. While in the cab, Shirō hallucinates that Tamura is driving the cab, and it crashes, killing Yukiko. After her funeral, Shirō seeks solace in the arms of strip bar worker and Kyōichi's grieving girlfriend Yoko (Akiko Ono), who discovers Shirō's culpability for the hit-and-run after sleeping with him and, with Kyōichi's mother, plots revenge.
Shirō receives a telegram that his mother, Ito, who lives in a country-side retirement community run by his father, Gōzō, is dying and rushes to see her. There, he meets the other residents including a disgraced painter, Ensai, who is painting a portrait of Hell, a former reporter, Akagawa, a corrupt detective, Hariya, and the community doctor, Dr. Kasuma. He meets Sachiko (also played by Mitsuya), a nurse and Ensai's daughter, who bears an uncanny resemblance to Yukiko, and is taking care of his mother. During his stay, Shirō and Sachiko become close while each of the residents' sordid activities is revealed: While Shirō's mother lies dying, his father carries on an open affair and also cheats the community of its money by cutting corners; the painter is wanted for a crime in another city; the detective threatens to turn the painter in unless he gives him Sachiko to marry; and the doctor knows his diagnoses are wrong, but feels that seeking a second opinion is too cumbersome. Both Mr. and Mrs. Yajima, both despondent after Yukiko's death, arrive by train to pay their respects to Shirō's mother. Ito dies, and Ensai blames Gōzō; decades ago, he and Ito were lovers before Gōzō came between them and married her leaving her unhappy. Inexplicably, Tamura appears and reveals that each of the residents has some complicity in a murder: Mr. Yajima killed his comrade during the war, stealing his water for himself; both the detective and reporter framed or slandered innocent men who then both committed suicide; and the doctor knew his diagnosis of Ito's condition was wrong, but chose not to tell anyone.
Yoko tracks Shirō down and meets with him on a rope bridge in the area. There she reveals her identity and attempts to shoot him while Kyōichi's mother watches from the trees, but she trips and falls to her death. Tamura appears, and the two struggle over the gun, and Tamura also falls into the gorge. Shirō stumbles back in time for the community's tenth anniversary party, where Gōzō has knowingly allowed cheap, rancid fish to be served to the residents. As the party descends into debauchery, Mr. and Mrs. Yajima both decide to leap in front of the train, killing themselves, and Gōzō's mistress falls to her death following an altercation. The residents die from consuming the tainted fish, and Kyōichi's mother sneaks into the party, poisoning the remaining residents' wine, killing them. Tamura, near death, stumbles into the party and shoots Sachiko, while Kyōichi's mother strangles Shirō to death and then commits suicide.
In Limbo, Shirō encounters Yukiko, who reveals that she was pregnant with his child, a baby girl named "Harumi", but has sent her floating away on the river of the underworld and begs Shirō to save her. Shirō enters Hell and is sentenced to punishment in the Eight Realms of Hell by Lord [[Yama (Buddhism and Chinese mythology)|Enma]] for his sins. While running through Hell to find his daughter, he encounters each of his acquaintances, who suffer, in gruesome fashion, a variety of punishments for their sins, such as being boiled and burned alive, dismembered and flayed, or cut apart and beaten by ogres, only to be revived to suffer anew. Meanwhile, Tamura taunts Shirō, saying there is no escape from Hell, before being butchered for giving his soul over to evil. In a realm filled with glass shards jutting from the ground, Shirō finds Sachiko, but their reunion is interrupted by Shirō's mother, who shamefully reveals that Sachiko is his sister: Shirō is actually Ensai's son, and Sachiko is actually her daughter, also a product of her later affair with Ensai. Shirō is disgusted with his family, and continues searching for his daughter, determined to live and save her. While caught in a vortex of damned souls, he finds his baby daughter helplessly rotating on the Buddhist wheel of life. Lord Enma gives Shirō one chance to save his daughter, otherwise she too will suffer for all eternity in Hell. As Yukiko, Sachiko, and his mother call to him, Shirō leaps onto the wheel, but cannot reach his daughter.
The moment is frozen in time, revealed to be nine o'clock: the exact time that everyone at the party has finally died, including Ensai, who has hanged himself after completing his portrait of Hell and set it on fire. In a final scene, both Sachiko and Yukiko stand smiling in peaceful light, calling to Shirō as sister and lover, respectively, with lotus petals falling around them, symbolizing mental and moral purity.
==Cast== * [[Shigeru Amachi]] as Shirō Shimizu, a young theology student who suffers guilt from his involvement in a hit-and-run on the night of his engagement to his girlfriend. * [[Yōichi Numata]] as Tamura, Shirō's dark and sociopathic classmate, who inexplicably knows everyone's sinful past, and was driving the car during the hit and run. * [[Utako Mitsuya]] as Yukiko Yajima, Shirō's loving girlfriend. ** and Sachiko Taniguchi, a young nurse who looks uncannily like Yukiko, and the daughter of a disgraced painter at a retirement community. * Hiroshi Izumida as Kyōichi 'Tiger' Shiga, a gangster hit and left for dead by Tamura and Shirō. * [[Kiyoko Tsuji]] as Kyōichi's Mother, who witnesses the accident and vows revenge. * [[Akiko Ono]] as Yoko, Kyōichi's girlfriend who swears revenge on Shirō with Kyōichi's Mother. * Hiroshi Hayashi as Gōzō Shimizu, Shirō's lecherous and greedy father who runs a dilapidated retirement center. * Kimie Tokudaij as Ito Shimizu, Shirō's sickly mother. * [[Jun Ōtomo]] as Ensai Taniguchi, an alcoholic painter, who is father to Sachiko. He is commissioned to paint a depiction of Hell. * Akiko Yamashita as Kinuko, Gōzō's shameless mistress. * Torahiko Nakamura as Professor Yajima, Shirō's teacher and father to Yukiko. * Fumiko Miyata as Mrs. Yajima, Yukiko's fragile mother. * Tomohiko Ōtani as Dr. Kusama, a negligent doctor of the retirement community. * Kôichi Miya as Journalist Akagawa, a resident of the community with a soiled past. * Hiroshi Shinguji (as Hiroshi Shingûji) as Detective Hariya, a corrupt detective who threatens to turn Ensai in unless he gives Sachiko to him for marriage. * Sakutarō Yamakawa as the Fisherman. * Kanjūrō Arashi (uncredited) as [[Yama (Buddhism and Chinese mythology)|Lord Enma]], the King of Hell.
==Production== {{expand section|date=October 2015}} [[Nobuo Nakagawa]] asked [[Ichirō Miyagawa]] to write the script, which was originally supposed to be called ''Heaven and Hell'', under order of [[Film producer|producer]] [[Mitsugu Okura]].<ref name="Criterion Collection">{{cite video |people=[[Ichirō Miyagawa|Miyagawa, Ichirō]] (Writer) |date=2007-03-13 |title=Jigoku, DVD Extra: ''Building the Inferno |medium=DVD |publisher=[[Criterion Collection]] |time=}}</ref> Mitsugu Okura read the [[Screenplay|script]] and angrily said to Miyagawa that "Heaven is nowhere to be seen in this script!", to which Miyagawa jokingly replied that he would write about Heaven in the sequel.<ref name="Criterion Collection"/> Actor [[Yoichi Numata]] played Tamura in the film, and expressed that he had tried to analyze the role, but couldn't find the best way to play it.<ref>{{cite video |people=[[Yoichi Numata|Numata, Yoichi]] (Actor) |date=2007-03-13 |title=Jigoku, DVD Extra: ''Building the Inferno |medium=DVD |publisher=[[Criterion Collection]] |time=}}</ref>
The film was not expected to be well received, as [[Shintoho]] [[Film studio|studio]] was considered to be a maker of low-budget, gory films. ''Jigoku'' was made in a hurry, and was the last Shintoho production. For the scenes which take place in [[hell]], the cast and crew used Shintoho's largest soundstage and put dirt over it.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite video |people=[[Mamoru Morita|Morita, Mamoru]] (Cinematographer) |date=2007-03-13 |title=Jigoku, DVD Extra: ''Building the Inferno |medium=DVD |publisher=[[Criterion Collection]] |time=}}</ref> In a recent documentary, a crew member said that normally it would be just the crew helping to build the sets, but because it was Shintoho's last production, all the [[Extra (actor)|extra]]s were helping.<ref>{{cite video |date=2007-03-13 |title=Jigoku, DVD Extra: ''Building the Inferno |medium=DVD |publisher=[[Criterion Collection]] |time=}}</ref> [[Mamoru Morita]] said that Nobuo Nakagawa tried in many ways to make ''Jigoku'' different from other [[Horror Film|horror]] films from the time.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
In 1979, the acclaimed [[Nikkatsu]] Roman Porno director [[Tatsumi Kumashiro]] remade ''Jigoku'' for [[Toei Company|Toei]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Sharp|first=Jasper|title=Behind the Pink Curtain: The Complete History of Japanese Sex Cinema|page= 137|year=2008|publisher=FAB Press|location=Guildford|isbn=978-1-903254-54-7}}</ref>
==Release== {{expand section|date=July 2018}} ''Jigoku'' was theatrically released in Japan on July 30, 1960.{{sfn|Galbraith IV|1996|p=359}} ===Home media=== The film was released on [[DVD]] in North America from the [[Criterion Collection]] on September 19, 2006.<ref name="criterionrelease">{{cite web |title=The Criterion Collection - Cult Movies |url=https://www.criterion.com/shop/collection/1-cult-movies |website=Criterion.com |publisher=Criterion Collection |accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref> ==Reception== {{expand section|date=July 2018}} ===Later reception=== Later reviews of the film have been more positive, with many critics now recognizing it as a cornerstone for Nakagawa’s career. [[Dennis Schwartz]] from ''[[Ozus' World Movie Reviews]]'' awarded the film a grade "A", calling it "[a] disquieting morality tale based upon the Buddhist concept of an afterlife". Schwartz praised the film's performances, and visuals which he felt 'acted as a lurid study of sin without salvation'.<ref name="schwartz06">{{cite web |last1=Schwartz |first1=Dennis |title=jigoku |url=http://homepages.sover.net/~ozus/jigoku.htm |website=Sover.net |publisher=Dennis Schwartz |accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref> In an [[Film essay|essay]] for the Criterion Collection, Chuck Stephens wrote, "Overflowing with brackish ponds of bubbling pus, brain-rattling disjunctions of sound and image, and at times almost dauntingly incomprehensible plot twists and eye-assaulting bouts of brutish montage, ''Jigoku'' is more than merely a boundary-pummeling classic of the horror genre—it’s as lurid a study of sin without salvation as the silver screen has ever seen."<ref name="stephens06">{{cite web |last1=Stephens |first1=Chuck |title=The Criterion Collection - The Current - Jigoku: Hell on Earth |url=https://www.criterion.com/current/posts/448-jigoku-hell-on-earth |website=Criterion.com |publisher=Chuck Stephens |accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref> Brett Gallman from ''Oh, the Horror!'' praised the film, calling it "a masterpiece in visual and abstract horror". Gallman praised the film's performances, eerie score, Nakagawa’s direction, and "vivid color palette".<ref name="gallman10">{{cite web |last1=Gallman |first1=Brett |title=Horror Reviews - Jigoku (1960) |url=http://www.oh-the-horror.com/page.php?id=713 |website=Oh the Horror.com |publisher=Brett Gallman |accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref> ''HorrorNews.net'' stated in their review of the film that, "Although this film contains effects that are outdated by modern standards, it is a very powerful story that is based upon the Buddhist belief that sins are atoned for in the afterlife."<ref name="hnreview10">{{cite web |title=Film Review: Jigoku (1960) |url=http://horrornews.net/11385/film-review-jigoku-1960/ |website=HorrorNews.net |publisher=Scarlett OTerror |accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref>
The film has developed a [[cult film|cult following]] over the years and is now considered a cult classic.<ref name="schwartz06" /><ref name="cultfilm">{{cite web|url=https://www.criterion.com/explore/1-cult-movies|title=Cult Movies|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use British English|date=May 2015}} [[File:J.B.Buckstone.jpg|thumb|John Baldwin Buckstone]] '''John Baldwin Buckstone''' (14 September 1802 – 31 October 1879) was an English actor, playwright and comedian who wrote 150 plays, the first of which was produced in 1826.
He starred as a comic actor during much of his career for various periods at the [[Adelphi Theatre]] and the [[Haymarket Theatre]], managing the Haymarket from 1853 to 1877.
==Biography== Buckstone was born in [[Hoxton]], London, the son of John Buckstone, a retired shopkeeper, and his wife Elizabeth (née Baldwin).<ref>[http://interactive.ancestry.co.uk/2056/32515_1831109331_0013-01511/852351?backurl=http%3a%2f%2fsearch.ancestry.co.uk%2f%2fcgi-bin%2fsse.dll%3frank%3d1%26new%3d1%26MSAV%3d1%26gss%3dangs-c%26gsfn%3dJohn%2bBaldwin%2b%26gsln%3dBuckstone%26msbdy%3d1802%26msbpn__ftp%3dHoxton%252c%2bMiddlesex%252c%2bEngland%26msbpn%3d85853%26msbpn_PInfo%3d8-%257c0%257c0%257c3257%257c3251%257c0%257c0%257c0%257c5275%257c85853%257c0%257c%26msddy%3d1879%26msgdy%3d1857%26msydy%3d1857%26gskw%3dActor%26cpxt%3d1%26uidh%3drc8%26msbdm%3d9%26_83004003-n_xcl%3df%26cp%3d11%26mssng0%3dIsabella%26mssns0%3dCopeland%26pcat%3d34%26h%3d852351%26recoff%3d21%2b22%26db%3dSurreyMarriage%26indiv%3d1%26ml_rpos%3d19&ssrc=&backlabel=ReturnRecord London and Surrey, England, Marriage Bonds and Allegations, 1597–1921 for Elizabeth Baldwin], [[Ancestry.com]] (pay to view)</ref><ref name=ODNB>Roy, Donald. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/3876 "Buckstone, John Baldwin (1802–1879)"], ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, January 2008, accessed 3 January 2015</ref> He was educated at Walworth Grammar School and was briefly apprenticed on a naval ship at age 10 but returned to school. He studied law and was articled to a [[solicitor]] but turned to acting by age 19.<ref name=Timesobit>''[[The Times]]'', 1 November 1879, p. 5</ref>
===Early career=== Buckstone first joined a travelling troupe in 1821 as Gabriel in ''The Children in the Wood''.<ref name=NYTimes>[https://www.nytimes.com/1879/11/01/archives/death-of-jb-buckstone-a-veteran-actor-playwright-and-manager-the.html ''New York Times'' obituary], p. 2, 1 November 1879</ref> and toured for three years, mostly in the southeast of England. He found a mentor in [[Edmund Kean]]. He made his first London appearance, on 30 January 1823, at the [[Surrey Theatre]], as Ramsay in ''[[The Fortunes of Nigel]]''. In 1824 he joined that theatre and played Peter Smink in ''The Armistice'' with great success. He also began to write plays.<ref name=Waddy>Waddy, Frederick. [https://archive.org/details/cartoonportraits00wadduoft ''Cartoon Portraits and Biographical Sketches of Men of the Day''], Tinsley brothers: London (1873)</ref>
[[File:Buckstone.jpg|thumb|left|Portrait of Buckstone]] His successes led to his engagement in 1827 at the [[Adelphi Theatre]], where he remained as the leading low comedian until 1833. Buckstone's acting was described as "a union of shrewdness and drollery, with their interaction upon each other ... was irresistibly comic."<ref>Marston, Westland. ''Our Recent Actors'' (Boston, 1888), vol. II, p. 90</ref> Buckstone wrote most of his plays in the first half of his career, and many of these were produced at the Adelphi. As his acting career reached the height of its success, his playwriting output declined.<ref name=utility>Stedman, Jane W. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3205899 "General Utility: Victorian Author-Actors from Knowles to Pinero",] ''Educational Theatre Journal'', Vol. 24, No. 3, October 1972, pp. 289–301, The Johns Hopkins University Press</ref> At the Adelphi, he appeared as Bobby Trot in his first really successful play, the melodrama ''Luke the Labourer'' (1827), which he had written in 1826.<ref name=utility/> Other well known plays were ''Wreck Ashore'' (1830) and ''Forgery'' (1832)<ref name=Timesobit/> Perhaps the most successful of these early plays was his 1833 play, ''The Bravo'', based on [[James Fenimore Cooper]]'s [[The Bravo|novel of the same name]].<ref name=NYTimes/>
===Peak years=== He first appeared at the [[Haymarket Theatre]] during the summer season in 1833, also writing plays for this theatre, including ''Ellen Wartham'' (1833). Another hit for the Haymarket was the drama ''Thirty Years of a Woman's Life''. At that theatre, his acting was praised in ''The Housekeeper'' by [[Douglas Jerrold]] (1833), ''Pyramus and Thisbe'', and in his own plays, ''Uncle John'', ''Rural Felicity'' and ''Agnes de Vere'' (all in 1834). He stayed at the Haymarket until 1838, producing ''The Dream at Sea'' among other plays.<ref name=Timesobit/>
In 1839–40 he returned to the Adelphi to write and star in a number of plays, including his extraordinarily successful play ''[[Jack Sheppard]]'', based on the [[Jack Sheppard (novel)|novel of the same name]] published that year by [[William Harrison Ainsworth]]. After his return from a visit to the United States in 1840, where he met with little success, Buckstone played in his own play, ''Married Life'', at the Haymarket. He then appeared at several London theatres, among them the [[Lyceum Theatre (London)|Lyceum]], where he was Box at the first representation of ''[[Box and Cox (farce)|Box and Cox]]'', by [[John Maddison Morton]], in 1847.<ref>[http://www.royalengineers.ca/BoxandCox02.html ''Box and Cox'']</ref> There he also created the role of Bob, in [[Dion Boucicault]]'s ''Old Heads and Young Hearts'', and played several other memorable roles, including, Slowboy in ''Cricket on the Hearth'', Dan in ''[[John Bull]]'', MacDunnum of Dunnum in ''A School for Scheming'', Scrub in ''[[The Beaux' Stratagem]]'' and Golightly in ''Lend Me Five Shillings'', and several [[Shakespeare]] roles. For the Adelphi, he wrote ''The Green Bushes'' and ''The Flowers of the Forest'', both in 1847. He also dramatised ''[[The Last Days of Pompeii]]''.<ref name=Timesobit/><ref name=NYTimes/>
He returned to the Haymarket in 1848, writing and playing in ''An Alarming Sacrifice'', ''Leap Year'' and ''A Serious Family''. During this period, he memorably played Moses in Stirling Coyne's adaptation of ''[[The Vicar of Wakefield]]'', Appleface in Jerrold's ''Catspaw'', Shadowly Softhead in [[Edward Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Baron Lytton|Lord Lytton]]'s ''Not as Bad as We Seem'' and in many Shakespeare productions with Mr. and Mrs. [[Charles Kean]].<ref name=Timesobit/>
===Later years=== [[File:W.S. Gilbert's burlesque comedy, Engaged.jpg|''[[Engaged (play)|Engaged]]'' at the Haymarket in 1877|thumb|right|250px]] He became lessee of the Haymarket from 1853 to 1877. For this theatre, he continued to write plays and [[farce]]s, though markedly fewer than before. As manager of the Haymarket, he surrounded himself with an admirable and effective ensemble company, including [[Edward Askew Sothern]], [[Henry Compton (actor)|Henry Compton]], Mr. and Mrs. [[Charles James Mathews]] and [[William Hunter Kendal|the Kendals]]. He produced the plays of [[James Planché]], [[Thomas William Robertson]], [[Tom Taylor]], [[John Oxenford]], [[H. J. Byron]] and [[W. S. Gilbert]], as well as his own, and in most of these he acted. Buckstone's management made the Haymarket into the premier comedy theatre of the age. Buckstone's own gifts in comedy contributed much to the theatre's remarkable success. According to ''The Times'', "Few men... have possessed to a greater extent the power of communicating the spirit of mirth to an audience. ... He was helped, too, in his vocation by remarkable physical attributes" and a peculiar, hilarious voice.<ref name=Timesobit/>
In the 1850s, Buckstone produced ''An Unequal Match'' and Taylor's ''The Overland Route'', ''A Hero of Romance'' by Westland Marston, and ''Home'' by Robertson. In 1862, Buckstone produced a 496-night run of ''[[Our American Cousin]]'', with Sothern in his most famous role as [[Lord Dundreary]]. Robertson's ''[[David Garrick (play)|David Garrick]]'' was a hit in 1864, also with Sothern in the title role. W. S. Gilbert premiered seven of his plays at the Haymarket during this time including his blank verse "fairy comedies" starring the Kendals, such as ''[[The Palace of Truth]]'' (1870), ''[[Pygmalion and Galatea (play)|Pygmalion and Galatea]]'' (1871) and ''[[The Wicked World]]'' (1873). Buckstone also produced Gilbert's dramas, ''[[Charity (play)|Charity]]'' (1874) and ''[[Dan'l Druce, Blacksmith]]'' (1876), as well as his 1877 farce ''[[Engaged (play)|Engaged]]''. In 1873 Buckstone introduced the innovation of matinées starting at 2.00 pm. By the mid-1870s, however, Buckstone's company was disbanding, and in 1877, ill and bankrupt after sustaining heavy losses, he gave up management of the theatre.<ref name=Timesobit/>
===Personal life, death and ghost=== Buckstone was first married in 1828 to Anne Maria Honeyman,<ref>Parish Register (marriages) of St John the Evangelist, Lambeth, 1828, p. 168, No.502; London Metropolitan Archives</ref> with whom he had at least five children<ref>Parish Registers (births) of: St John the Evangelist, Lambeth; St Mary, Lambeth; Holy Trinity, Brompton; Caterham Church (Bishop's Transcripts); London Metropolitan Archives</ref> before she died in 1844.<ref>Register of Deaths Index, 1844 Q3, vol. 3, p. 89, General Register Office, London</ref> For many years, Buckstone was closely associated with the actress [[Fanny Fitzwilliam|Fanny Copeland Fitzwilliam]], who was widowed in 1852 and whom he was engaged to marry in 1854. She died of cholera a month before the wedding.<ref>Knight, Joseph. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/9657/?back=,3876 "Fitzwilliam, Fanny Elizabeth (1801–1854)"], rev. J. Gilliland, ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press (2004), accessed 3 January 2015</ref> In 1857 Buckstone married Fanny's cousin Isabella Copeland, the great-niece of the theatre manager [[Robert Copeland (theatre manager)|Robert Copeland]], and they had 12 children between 1857 and 1876.<ref>General Register Office, London, for the years from 1857 to 1876</ref> Their daughter, [[Lucy Isabella Buckstone]] and their sons [[J. C. Buckstone|John Copeland Buckstone]] and Rowland Buckstone also took to the stage.<ref>Parker, John. [https://books.google.com/books?id=_MMzAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA71 "Buckstone, J. C."], ''Who's Who in the Theatre'', 1916, p. 71. Retrieved 29 July 2013</ref>
After three years of ill health, Buckstone died at his home in Lower [[Sydenham]] in 1879 at the age of 77.
According to director Nigel Everett and stagehands at the Haymarket Theatre, Buckstone's ghost has often been seen at the theatre, particularly during comedies and "when he appreciates things" playing there.<ref name=ghost>Adams, Stephen. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/theatre-news/6087811/Patrick-Stewart-saw-ghost-performing-Waiting-for-Godot.html "Patrick Stewart saw ghost performing Waiting for Godot",] ''The Daily Telegraph'', 25 August 2009</ref> In 2009, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that the actor [[Patrick Stewart]] saw the ghost standing in the wings during a performance of ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' at the Haymarket.<ref name=ghost/>

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|1992 Los Angeles riots}} {{Infobox Film Movement | name = L.A. Rebellion | image = | image_size = | caption = | yearsactive = 1967–89 | country = United States | majorfigures = [[Charles Burnett (director)|Charles Burnett]], [[Larry Clark (filmmaker)|Larry Clark]], [[Julie Dash]], [[Jamaa Fanaka]], [[Haile Gerima]], [[Billy Woodberry]] | influences = [[Cinema of Africa|African cinema]], [[Cinema of Cuba|Cuban cinema]], [[Cinema Novo]], [[European art cinema]], [[French New Wave]], [[Italian neorealism]], [[Latin American cinema]] | influenced = }}
The '''L.A. Rebellion''' film movement, sometimes referred to as the "'''Los Angeles School of Black Filmmakers'''", or the '''UCLA Rebellion''', refers to the new generation of young [[Africa]]n and [[African-American]] filmmakers who studied at the [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] Film School in the late-1960s to the late-1980s and have created a quality Black Cinema that provides an alternative to [[classical Hollywood cinema]].<ref name='LAR-CANBC'>{{cite book |last1= |first1= |author-link1= |last2= |first2= |author-link2= |last3= |first3= |author-link3= |last4= |first4= |author-link4= |last5= |first5= |author-link5= |display-authors= |author-mask= |last-author-amp= |date= |year=2015 |orig-year= |chapter= |trans-chapter= |chapter-url= |chapter-format= |editor1-last=Field |editor1-first=Allyson Nadia |editor1-link= |editor2-last=Horak |editor2-first=Jan-Christopher |editor2-link= |editor3-last=Stewart |editor3-first=Jacqueline Najuma |editor3-link= |editor4-last= |editor4-first= |editor4-link= |editor5-last= |editor5-first= |editor5-link= |display-editors= |title=L.A. Rebellion: |script-title=Creating a New Black Cinema |trans-title= |url= |deadurl= |format= |type= |series= |language= |volume= |issue= |others= |edition= |location=Oakland, California |publisher=University of California Press |publication-date= |page= |pages= |at= |nopp= |arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archive-url= |archive-date= |access-date= |via= |registration= |subscription= |lay-summary= |lay-source= |lay-date= |quote=The group of Black filmmakers that have come to be known as the L.A. Rebellion created a watershed body of work that strives to perform the revolutionary act of humanizing Black people on screen. |name-list-format= |mode= |postscript= |ref= }}</ref><ref name='UCLA-LAR'>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/events/2011-10-07/la-rebellion-creating-new-black-cinema |title=L.A. Rebellion: Creating a New Black Cinema |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work= |publisher=UCLA School of Theater, Film & Television|location=Los Angeles, California |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|format= |arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doibroken= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc = |embargo= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate=2011-10-02 |quote=Beginning in the late 1960s, a number of promising African and African-American students entered the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television, recruited under a concerted initiative to be more responsive to various communities of color. From that first class through the late 1980s, and continuing well beyond their college days, these filmmakers came to represent the first sustained undertaking to forge an alternative Black Cinema practice in the United States. Along the way, they created fascinating, provocative and visionary films that have earned an impressive array of awards and accolades at festivals around the world, in addition to blazing new paths into the commercial market. |ref= |postscript=}}</ref><ref name='Washington-Post'>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/01/AR2007060100494.html |title=From L.A. Hotbed, Black Filmmakers' Creativity Flowered |first=Ann |last=Hornaday |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=2007-06-03 |month= |year= |work=Washington Post |publisher= |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doibroken= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc = |embargo= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate=2011-10-02 |quote=In 1967, after studying electrical engineering at Los Angeles Community College, Burnett arrived at UCLA to study film. For the next 10 years, UCLA students would develop a fecund, cosmopolitan and politically engaged movement that came to be unofficially known as the Los Angeles School of Black Filmmakers. |ref= |postscript=}}</ref><ref name='FilmRef'>{{cite web |url=http://www.filmreference.com/encyclopedia/Academy-Awards-Crime-Films/African-American-Cinema-THE-L-A-REBELLION.html |title=The L.A. Rebellion |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work= |publisher=Film Reference |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doibroken= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc = |embargo= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate=2011-10-02 |quote=Armed with a knowledge of "traditional" film history now infused with an introduction to the Third Cinema movement and exposure to revolutionary films from Latin America and Africa, these filmmakers took advantage of their "outsider" positioning, reinvigorating the push for a politically driven cinema... |ref= |postscript=}}</ref><ref name='LAWeekly-6Oct2011'>{{cite news |title=L.A. Rebellion:Creating a New Black Cinema |author= |first=John |last=Patterson |authorlink= |authorlink2= |author2= |author3= |author4= |author5= |author6= |author7= |url=http://www.laweekly.com/2011-10-06/film-tv/l-a-rebellion-creating-a-new-black-cinema/ |format= |agency= |newspaper=L.A. Weekly |publisher= |location=Los Angeles, California |isbn= |issn= |oclc= |pmid= |pmd= |bibcode= |doi= |id= |date=2011-10-06 |page= |pages= |at= |accessdate=2011-10-10 |language= |trans-title=|quote=This collection of the highlights of the legendary but only partially understood African-American film explosion at UCLA in the '70s and early '80s is a priceless work of excavation and restoration, and as an L.A.-specific filmic event it's unlikely to be surpassed in the near future. |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |ref=}}</ref>
==Background== In June 1953, [[Ike Jones]] became the first African American to graduate from the UCLA Film School.<ref name='Jet-16Oct1952'>{{cite journal |editor1-first=John H. |editor1-last=Johnson |date=October 16, 1952 |title=Football Player To Pioneer In Hollywood Films |journal=Jet |volume=2 |issue=25 |page=54 |publisher=Johnson Publishing Company, Inc. |location=Chicago, Illinois}}</ref> In the next 15 years, the numbers of African-American filmmakers remained small. One of those was [[Vantile Whitfield]], who founded the Performing Arts Society of Los Angeles in 1964 and received a master's degree at UCLA in 1967.<ref name='Post-Obit'>{{cite news |title=Arts Administrator, Playwright Vantile Whitfield Dies |author= |first=Yvonne |last=Shinhoster Lamb |authorlink= |authorlink2= |author2= |author3= |author4= |author5= |author6= |author7= |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A29685-2005Jan22 |format= |agency= |newspaper=Washington Post |publisher= |location=Washington, DC |isbn= |issn= |oclc= |pmid= |pmd= |bibcode= |doi= |id= |date=2005-01-23 |page= |pages= |at= |accessdate=2011-11-13 |language= |trans-title=|quote=He graduated with a bachelor's degree in theater and design from Howard University in 1957 and a master's degree in film production from the University of California at Los Angeles in 1967. In the years between colleges, he started community theaters. |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |ref=}}</ref> By the late 1960s, in the midst of [[affirmative action]], the number of Black students steadily increased. Among this new crop of artists were [[Charles Burnett (director)|Charles Burnett]], an engineering student who had attended [[Los Angeles City College]], and [[Haile Gerima]], an Ethiopian filmmaker who had recently moved from Chicago. Unlike their predecessors, they eschewed Hollywood conventions and were influenced by films from Latin America, [[Italian neorealism]], European art films, and the emerging [[cinema of Africa]]. They were among the first of what became known as the "Los Angeles School of Black Filmmakers."<ref name='Washington-Post'/><ref name='Images'>{{cite web |url=http://www.imagesjournal.com/issue05/features/black.htm |title=Black Independent Cinema and the Influence of Neo-Realism |first=Chris |last=Norton |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work=Images: A Journal of Film and Popular Culture |publisher= |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doibroken= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc = |embargo= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate=2011-10-02 |quote=Most notable of these filmmakers were Charles Burnett, Billy Woodberry, Haile Gerima and Julie Dash. Drawing on their own experiences in the black community and varied political and social discourses of the time including black nationalism, the Civil Rights Movement, the Women's Movement, anti-war rhetoric and Marxist doctrine, these filmmakers sought an aesthetic and mode of representation and narration that spoke to the realities of black existence and the state of the black family under a hegemonic rule of white racism and subordination. |ref= |postscript=}}</ref>
In the wake of the [[Watts Riots]] and other forms of [[Rebellion|social unrest]], such as a 1969 shoot-out on the UCLA campus involving [[Ron Karenga]]'s US Organization, Burnett and several other students of color helped push the university to start an [[Ethnographic film|ethnographic]] studies program.<ref name='LAWeekly-6Oct2011'/> Elyseo J. Taylor, who was the only Black instructor at the UCLA Film School in the early 1970s, was an influential instructor in that program.<ref name='LAR-Elyseo'>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/events/2011-11-20/black-art-black-artists-1971-festival-mask-1982-varnettes-world-study-young-artist |title=Black Art, Black Artists (1971); Festival of Mask (1982); Varnette's World: A Study of a Young Artist (1979); Trumpetistically, Clora Bryant (1989) |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work= |publisher=UCLA Film & Television Archive |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|format= |arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doibroken= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc = |embargo= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate=2011-10-02 |quote=As the only Black faculty member in UCLA's film school, Elyseo Taylor was an influential teacher and advocate for students of color. |ref= |postscript=}}</ref>
[[Teshome Gabriel]], a film scholar and historian, began teaching at UCLA in 1974 and became both a colleague and mentor to many filmmakers associated with the movement.<ref name='Gabriel-Obit'>{{cite web |url=http://www.tft.ucla.edu/news/obituary/738-teshome-gabriel_obit/ |title=Cinema & Media Studies professor was an internationally recognized expert on Third World Cinema |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=2010-06-10 |month= |year= |work= |publisher=UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television |location=Los Angeles, California |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|format= |arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doibroken= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc = |embargo= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate= |quote=As a faculty member and student at TFT in the 1970s and early 1980s, Gabriel was both a colleague of and a mentor to the African-American and African student filmmakers whose work came to define the Los Angeles School of Black Filmmakers, also known as the "L.A. Rebellion." The group included such soon-to-be-celebrated artists as Charles Burnett, Larry Clark, Julie Dash, Haile Gerima, Ben Caldwell, Billy Woodberry, Alile Sharon Larkin, Jacqueline Frazier, Jamaa Fanaka and Barbara McCullough. The UCLA Film & Television Archive is currently preparing a major film exhibition scheduled for 2011 which will explore this key artistic movement.|ref= |postscript=}}</ref>
==Identification of movement== Film scholar [[Clyde Taylor]] coined the term "L.A. Rebellion" to describe the filmmakers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/blogs/archival-spaces/2011/10/28/what%E2%80%99s-name-la-rebellion|title=What's in a Name? L.A. Rebellion {{!}} UCLA Film & Television Archive|website=www.cinema.ucla.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref><ref name='Online-Encyclopedia'>{{cite web |url=http://encyclopedia.jrank.org/articles/pages/3229/Ucla-Rebellion-The.html |title=The UCLA Rebellion |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work= |publisher=Online Encyclopedia |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doibroken= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc = |embargo= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate=2011-10-29 |quote=This is a term coined by film scholar Clyde Taylor when referring to a group of African American and other minority students who attended film school at the {{sic|hide=y|reason=duplicate 'the' in source}} University of California, Los Angeles during the 1970s and initiated a black independent filmmaking movement.|ref= |postscript=}}</ref>
In the spring of 1997, Doc Films, a student-run film society based at the [[University of Chicago]], hosted one of the first retrospectives of L.A. Rebellion films. [[Jacqueline Stewart]], an associate professor at the university, helped coordinate the program. This series included works by [[Charles Burnett (director)|Charles Burnett]], [[Haile Gerima]] and [[Julie Dash]].<ref name='Doc-LAR'>{{cite web |url=http://blackfilm.uchicago.edu/campus_resources/doc_films.shtml |title=Doc Films |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work= |publisher=University of Chicago |location=Chicago, Illinois |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doibroken= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc = |embargo= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate= |quote= |ref= |postscript=}}</ref>
In Fall 2011, UCLA Film and Television Archive programmed a major retrospective of these films entitled, "L.A. Rebellion: Creating a New Black Cinema." The series was funded by the Getty Foundation as a part of ''Pacific Standard Time: Art in L.A. 1945-1980''.<ref name="UCLA-LAR" /><ref name="LAWeekly-6Oct2011" /> Preceding the program, the UCLA curatorial team conducted oral histories, identifying nearly fifty filmmakers, many of whom had remained invisible for decades. Papers and films by the filmmakers were collected and numerous films were preserved before screening. A catalog was also published, "L.A. Rebellion: Creating a New Black Cinema (Los Angeles, 2011), which accompanied the touring program through more than fifteen cities in North America and Europe.
==List of important figures of the L.A. Rebellion movement==
===Filmmakers=== Many of the filmmakers listed below, while primarily known as writer/directors, worked in multiple capacities on various film productions through their early careers.
{{col-begin}}{{col-2}} * Gay Abel-Bey * [[Anita W. Addison]] * Shirikiana Aina * Don Amis * Melvonna Ballenger * [[S. Torriano Berry]] * [[Carroll Parrott Blue]] * Storme' Bright (Sweet) * [[Charles Burnett (director)|Charles Burnett]] * [[Ben Caldwell (filmmaker)|Ben Caldwell]] * [[Larry Clark (filmmaker)|Larry Clark]] * [[Julie Dash]] * [[Zeinabu irene Davis]] * Pierre Desir * Alicia Dhanifu * Omah Diegu (Ijeoma Iloputaife) {{col-2}}
* [[Jamaa Fanaka]] * Jacqueline Frazier * [[Haile Gerima]] * [[Alile Sharon Larkin]] * [[Barbara McCullough]] * Bernard Nicolas * O.Funmilayo Makarah * Thomas Penick * Imelda Sheen (Mildred Richard) * Monona Wali * Grayling WIlliams * Robert Wheaton * Iverson White * [[Billy Woodberry]]
{{col-end}}
===Actors=== The following actors appeared in various L.A. Rebellion films and are to some degree associated with the movement:
{{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * Adisa Anderson * [[Haskell V. Anderson III]] * Barbara-O * Charles David Brooks III * Angela Burnett {{col-2}} * Nate Hardman * Kaycee Moore * [[Sy Richardson]] * Henry G. Sanders {{col-end}}
===Others=== The following have supported the work of L.A. Rebellion filmmakers as mentors and/or scholars:
* Clyde Taylor, film critic, coined the phrase "L.A. Rebellion" to describe this movement * Elyseo J. Taylor, filmmaker and instructor at [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]]<ref name='LAR-Elyseo'/> * [[Vantile Whitfield]], an early African-American UCLA Film School graduate and founder of the Performing Arts Society of Los Angeles (PASLA)<ref name='Post-Obit'/> * [[Teshome Gabriel]], film scholar and Professor at UCLA<ref name='Gabriel-Obit'/> * Ntongela Masilela, film scholar * Jacqueline Najuma Stewart, film scholar and Associate Professor at [[Northwestern University]] * Allyson Nadia Field, Associate Professor of Cinema and Media Studies and African American Studies at UCLA * Jan-Christopher Horak, Director of the UCLA Film & Television Archive
==List of notable L.A. Rebellion films== The following is a chronological list of [[Short film|short]] and feature-length films from the L.A. Rebellion filmmakers that are generally considered to be seminal or notable.
* "Single Parent Family: Images in Black" (1976) * ''[[Jamaa Fanaka|Emma Mae]]'' (1976) * ''[[Harvest: 3,000 Years]]'' (1976) * ''[[Larry Clark (filmmaker)|Passing Through]]'' (1977) * ''[[Killer of Sheep]]'' (1978) * ''[[Bush Mama]]'' (1979) * ''[[Penitentiary (1979 film)|Penitentiary]]'' (1979) * ''Water Ritual #1: An Urban Rite of Purification'' (1979) * ''[[Ashes and Embers]]'' (1982) * ''[[A Different Image]]'' (1982) * ''[[Julie Dash|Illusions]]'' (1982) * ''[[Bless Their Little Hearts]]'' (1984) * ''[[To Sleep with Anger]]'' (1990) * ''[[Daughters of the Dust]]'' (1991) * ''[[Sankofa]]'' (1993) * ''[[The Glass Shield]]'' (1994)<ref>{{Citation|title=The Glass Shield|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109906/|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> * ''[[Adwa (film)|Adwa]]'' (1999) * ''[[Compensation (film)|Compensation]]'' (2000)
==Influence==
A documentary, ''Spirits of Rebellion: Black Cinema at UCLA,'' features interviews with many filmmakers associated with the movement. Directed by [[Zeinabu irene Davis]], it was screened as a work-in-progress on Saturday, October 8, 2011 as part of "L.A. Rebellion: Creating a New Black Cinema."<ref name='UCLA-LAR'/><ref name='Indiewire'>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/shadowandact/archives/preview_spirits_of_rebellion_-_a_documentary_film_about_the_l.a._rebellion_/ |title=Preview: "Spirits of Rebellion" - A Documentary Film About The L.A. Rebellion Film Movement |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |month= |year= |work= |publisher=Indiewire |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|format= |arxiv= |asin= |bibcode= |doi= |doibroken= |isbn= |issn= |jfm= |jstor= |lccn= |mr= |oclc= |ol= |osti= |pmc = |embargo= |pmid= |rfc= |ssrn= |zbl= |id= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl= |accessdate=2011-10-02 |quote= |ref= |postscript=}}</ref>
L.A. Rebellion films that have been voted onto the [[National Film Registry]]: ''[[Killer of Sheep]]'' (1990), ''[[Daughters of the Dust]]'' (2004) and ''[[Billy Woodberry|Bless Their Little Hearts]]'' (2013).
==See also== * [[Cinema of Africa|African cinema]] * [[Blaxploitation]] * [[Cinema of Cuba|Cuban cinema]] * [[Cult classic]] * [[European art cinema]] * [[French New Wave]] * [[Italian neorealism]] * [[Latin American cinema]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UcUmV-TaVGk Trailer of "Spirits of Rebellion" on YouTube] * [http://www.cinema.ucla.edu/la-rebellion L.A. Rebellion: Creating a New Black Cinema]
==Further reading== * Field, Allyson Nadia; Horak, Jan-Christopher; Stewart, Jacqueline Najuma, eds. (2015). ''L.A. Rebellion:'' Creating a New Black Cinema. Oakland, California: University of California Press.

[[es:Anexo:Autores de juegos de rol]] [[fi:Luettelo roolipelisuunnittelijoista]]

The following is a '''list of films released posthumously''' involving cast or crew members who either died during production or before the film's release.
==Directors== * All of [[Louis Le Prince]]'s surviving films, following his mysterious disappearance in 1890. * ''The Song of Songs'' (1918), released just seventeen days after Joseph Kaufman's death in the [[1918 flu pandemic]]. * ''[[The Top of New York]]'' (1922), released four months after [[William Desmond Taylor]]'s unsolved murder. * ''[[Such Men Are Dangerous]]'' (1930), released just over two months after [[Kenneth Hawks]]'s death in a two-plane crash over the [[Pacific Ocean]], while directing re-takes of aerial scenes for the film; Hawks, the younger brother of fellow director [[Howard Hawks]], was killed along with pilot Walter Ross Cook, cameraman [[George Eastman]], assistant director Ben Frankel, assistant director Max Gold, Tom Harris, Harry Johannes, Otho Jordan, pilot Halleck Rouse, and cinematographer [[Conrad Wells]] (also known as Abraham Fried). The finished film left Hawks uncredited. * ''[[The Sin Ship]]'' (1931), released two months after [[Louis Wolheim]]'s death from [[stomach cancer]]. * ''[[Tabu (1931 film)|Tabu]]'' (1931), released a week after [[F.W. Murnau]]'s death in a [[car accident]]. * ''[[The Viking (1931 film)|The Viking]]'' (1931), given its public release over three months after co-director [[Varick Frissell]]'s death in an explosion, along with 26 other crew members, on board the [[SS Viking|SS ''Viking'']]; the film, shot on location in [[Newfoundland]] by [[George Melford]] and Frissell in the winter of 1930-31, had been nominally completed and privately screened when Frissell decided it needed more sensational and realistic footage from the [[Labrador]] ice floes. Within days, Frissell and his crew re-joined the SS ''Viking'' (already used in the film) in order to shoot more footage; however, the ship quickly became trapped in ice about {{convert|8|mi|km|spell=in}} off the [[Horse Islands (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Horse Islands]]. On March 15, 1931, a cache of [[dynamite]] loaded on the vessel, being used for Frissell's film to add to the sensationalism of giant explosions of [[iceberg]]s, spontaneously blew up, destroying the back of the ship, blowing the stern off the vessel, and causing the ''Viking'' to catch fire and sink,<ref name="Rist">Rist 2001, p.230</ref><ref name="Rhodes95">Rhodes 2001, p. 95</ref><ref name="Film and Video - Early Days">{{cite web| url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/arts/early_days.html| title=Film and Video - Early Days| publisher=Newfoundland and Labrador Heritage| accessdate=December 16, 2007}}</ref> killing 27<ref name="Andrew McIntosh">{{cite web|url=http://tiff.net/CANADIANFILMENCYCLOPEDIA/content/films/viking |title=The Viking (White Thunder) |author=Andrew McIntosh |publisher=Canadian Film Encyclopedia |accessdate=March 29, 2012}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> members of the crew who were filming an iceberg, including Frissell and cinematographer Alexander Gustavus Penrod. The film as Frissell had left it was prepared for its posthumous release by associate producer Roy W. Gates. A French-language version of the film, ''Ceux du "Viking"'', shot simultaneously with the English-language version by French director René Ginet and also featuring Frissell's nature footage, was released in February 1932, 11 months after Frissell's death. * ''[[The Last of Mrs. Cheyney (1937 film)|The Last of Mrs. Cheyney]]'' (1937), released over a month after [[Richard Boleslawski]]'s death from [[cardiac arrest]]. * ''[[Titanic (1943 film)|Titanic]]'' (1943), released a year after [[Herbert Selpin]]'s supposed [[suicide]]. The film was completed by [[Werner Klingler]] who was not credited. * ''[[That Lady in Ermine]]'' (1948), released over eight months after [[Ernst Lubitsch]]'s death from a [[heart attack]]. * ''[[Ambush (1950 film)|Ambush]]'' (1950), released four months after [[Sam Wood]]'s death from a [[heart attack]]. * ''[[The Lovers of Montparnasse]]'' (1958), released over a year after [[Max Ophüls]]'s death from [[Rheumatic fever|rheumatic heart disease]], while shooting interiors on the film. Because he died in the middle of production, Ophüls's friend [[Jacques Becker]] took over after the director's death and finished the picture; it was dedicated to Ophüls's memory. * ''[[The Fly (1958 film)|The Fly]]'' (1958), released just over a week after [[Kurt Neumann (director)|Kurt Neumann]]'s death; ''[[Machete (1958 film)|Machete]]'' (1958), ''[[Watusi (film)|Watusi]]'' (1959), and ''[[Counterplot]]'' (1959) were also released posthumously. * ''[[The Hole (1960 film)|The Hole]]'' (1960), released less than a month after [[Jacques Becker]]'s sudden death; Becker, who had shot the film over a period of ten weeks, himself died of an undisclosed illness just two weeks after filming had wrapped. The picture was edited and assembled by [[Marguerite Renoir]] and [[Geneviève Vaury]] based on notes the director had written before his death; the completed film was nominated for a [[Palme d'Or]] at the [[1960 Cannes Film Festival|13th Cannes Film Festival]]. * ''[[A Dandy in Aspic]]'' (1968), released a year after [[Anthony Mann]]'s death from a heart attack. * ''[[The Honkers]]'' (1972), released five days after [[Steve Ihnat]]'s death from a heart attack, while attending the [[1972 Cannes Film Festival|25th Cannes Film Festival]]. * ''[[Salò, or the 120 Days of Sodom]]'' (1976), released twenty days after [[Pier Paolo Pasolini]]'s murder; the killer ran over him several times with Pasolini's own car while at the [[Ostia (Rome)|Ostia]] beach, near [[Rome]]. * ''[[The Greatest (1977 film)|The Greatest]]'' (1977), released four months after co-director [[Tom Gries]]'s death. * ''[[The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh]]'' (1977) and ''[[The Rescuers]]'' (1977), both released over a year after co-director [[John Lounsbery]]'s death as a result of surgical complications due to heart failure. * ''[[The Lovers' Wind]]'' (1978), released nearly eight years after [[Albert Lamorisse]]'s death in 1970 during shooting on the film, in a helicopter crash over a tour of [[Iran]]; his widow and son eventually completed the film, based on his production notes. It was nominated for a [[Posthumous recognition|posthumous]] [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Documentary Feature|Best Documentary Feature]].<ref name="Oscars1979">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1979 |title=The 51st Academy Awards (1979) Nominees and Winners |accessdate=2011-10-06|work=oscars.org}}</ref><ref name="NY Times">{{cite web |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/160976/Le-Vent-des-amoureux/overview |title=NY Times: The Lovers' Wind |accessdate=2008-11-16|work=NY Times}}</ref> * ''[[Watership Down (film)|Watership Down]]'' (1978), released over a year after [[John Hubley]]'s death during [[heart surgery]]; the film was eventually finished by [[Martin Rosen (director)|Martin Rosen]], and Hubley went uncredited. * ''[[Avalanche Express]]'' (1979), released over a year after [[Mark Robson]]'s death from a [[heart attack]] during filming; production was completed by his friend and fellow director, [[Monte Hellman]], who went uncredited for his work. * ''[[Freedom Road]]'' (1979), released nearly five months after [[Ján Kadár]]'s death. * ''[[Lightning Over Water]]'' (1980), released over a year after co-director [[Nicholas Ray]]'s death from [[lung cancer]]. * ''[[Querelle]]'' (1982), released two months after [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder]]'s death from [[heart failure]], due to a lethal mixture of [[sleeping pill]]s and [[cocaine]]. * ''[[The Dead (1987 film)|The Dead]]'' (1987), released almost four months after [[John Huston]]'s death from [[emphysema]] and complications from a [[heart attack]]. * ''[[Welcome Home (1989 film)|Welcome Home]]'' (1989), released nearly three months after [[Franklin J. Schaffner]]'s death from [[lung cancer]]. * ''[[The Nutcracker (1993 film)|The Nutcracker]]'' (1993) and ''[[Gypsy (1993 film)|Gypsy]]'' (1993), released four days and less than a month, respectively, after [[Emile Ardolino]]'s death due to complications from [[AIDS]]. * ''[[Blue Sky (film)|Blue Sky]]'' (1994), released nearly three years after [[Tony Richardson]]'s death from complications from [[AIDS]]. * ''[[Be a Wicked Woman]]'' (1990), shelved by director [[Kim Ki-young]] and screened publicly in 1998, following his death that same year in a house fire. * ''[[The Argument]]'' (1998) and ''[[Wild Side (1995 film)|Wild Side]]'' (1999), both released over two years after [[Donald Cammell]]'s suicide, following a disastrous recut of ''Wild Side'' by the film's producer. * ''[[Eyes Wide Shut]]'' (1999), released over four months after filmmaker [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s death from a [[heart attack]]. * ''[[A Decade Under the Influence (film)|A Decade Under the Influence]]'' (2003), released a year after [[Ted Demme]]'s death from a [[heart attack]]. * ''[[06/05]]'' (2004), released one month after [[Theo van Gogh (film director)|Theo van Gogh]]'s assassination. * ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Quiet Flows the Don (film)|ru|3=Тихий Дон (телесериал)|lt=Quiet Flows the Don}}'' (2006), released over twelve years after [[Sergei Bondarchuk]]'s death from a [[heart attack]]; disputes after filming had wrapped in 1994, over unfavorable clauses in Bondarchuk's contract with the Italian studio co-producing the film, left the tapes locked in a bank vault until some time after the director's death. Bondarchuk's son, [[Fyodor Bondarchuk]], assembled and edited the film for its final release on Russian television in 2006. * ''[[Everyone's Hero]]'' (2006), released two years after co-director [[Christopher Reeve]]'s death. * ''[[California Dreamin' (film)|California Dreamin']]'' (2007), released nearly nine months after [[Cristian Nemescu]]'s death in a taxi accident; the crash also killed the film's [[sound designer]], [[Andrei Toncu]]. * ''[[Waitress (film)|Waitress]]'' (2007), released just over six months after [[Adrienne Shelly]]'s murder at the hands of Diego Pillco; the Ecuadorian immigrant was caught stealing money from Shelly and decided to strangle her to death with a bedsheet, then frame it as a suicide by hanging. * ''[[The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency (TV series)|The No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency]]'' (2008), television film pilot, aired five days after [[Anthony Minghella]]'s death from a cancer-related [[hemorrhage]]. * ''[[Dhaam Dhoom]]'' (2008), a Tamil (Indian language) film co-written and partly directed by [[Jeeva (director)|Jeeva]] shortly before his death; it was completed by his widow, [[Anees Murugaraj]], and his longtime assistant, [[V. Manikandan]], and overseen by veteran cinematographer [[P. C. Sriram]]. * ''Buy a Suit'' (2008), released just over a month after [[Jun Ichikawa]]'s death from a [[cerebral hemorrhage]], following his collapse at a restaurant. * ''[[Casino Jack]]'' (2010), released just over a month after [[George Hickenlooper]]'s death from an accidental overdose of [[oxymorphone]] and alcohol. * ''[[Jab Tak Hai Jaan]]'' (2012), released just over a month after [[Yash Chopra]]'s death from [[dengue fever]] and multiple organ failure. * ''[[Hard to Be a God (2013 film)|Hard to Be a God]]'' (2013), released nearly nine months after [[Aleksei Yuryevich German]]'s sudden death; the film itself had been shot from 2000 to 2006, and was in the midst of intensive sound editing upon German's death. * ''[[The Uncondemned]]'' (2015), released just over two weeks after co-director Nick Louvel's death in a traffic collision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2015/09/24/filmmaker-nick-louvel-dead-crash/|title=Nick Louvel, NYC Filmmaker, Killed In East Hampton Car Crash « CBS New York|work=cbslocal.com}}</ref> * ''[[Traffic (2016 film)|Traffic]]'' (2016), released just over a month after [[Rajesh Pillai]]'s death from [[non-alcoholic liver cirrhosis]]. * ''[[The Aquatic Effect]]'' (2016), released nearly ten months after [[Sólveig Anspach]]'s death from breast cancer. * ''[[Odd Job (film)|Odd Job]]'' (2016), released almost a year after [[Pascal Chaumeil]]'s death from cancer. * ''[[The Other Side of the Wind]]'' (2018), released after thirty-three years after [[Orson Welles]]' death.
==Screenwriters== <!-- This list does NOT pertain to remakes in which the original writer was not involved with, or if the film is an adaptation of a work whose author died centuries earlier. Aside from unproduced screenplays finally being produced, the above-mentioned topics should not be included here --> * ''A Perfect Gentleman'' (1928), released just four days after Charles T. Horan's death from a [[heart attack]]. * ''[[King Kong (1933 film)|King Kong]]'' (1933), a year after [[Edgar Wallace]]'s death due to complications from [[diabetes]]. * ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' (1939), nearly four months after [[Sidney Howard]]'s death in a tractor accident; he had turned the ignition switch on and was cranking the engine to start it when it lurched forward, pinning him against the wall of his garage and crushing him to death. Posthumously, he won the 1939 Academy Award for Writing Adapted Screenplay for ''Gone with the Wind'', the first time a posthumous nominee for any Oscar won the award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oscars.about.com/od/historytrivia/a/academytrivia.htm|title=About.com Search - Find it now!|work=about.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828014252/http://oscars.about.com/od/historytrivia/a/academytrivia.htm|archivedate=2008-08-28|df=}}</ref> * ''[[The Night of the Hunter (film)|The Night of the Hunter]]'' (1955), four months after [[James Agee]]'s death from a [[heart attack]]. * ''[[Arabian Adventure]]'' (1979), released almost nine months after [[Brian Hayles]]'s death at the age of 48. * ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]'' (1980), over two years after [[Leigh Brackett]]'s death from [[Ovarian cancer|cancer]]. * ''[[Brotherly Love (1985 film)|Brotherly Love]]'' (1985), released a year after [[Ernest Tidyman]]'s death.<ref>{{cite web|last=O'Connor|first=John J.|title=JUDD HIRSCH AS TWINS IN 'BROTHERLY LOVE'|date=28 May 1985|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/05/28/arts/judd-hirsch-as-twins-in-brotherly-love.html?mcubz=1|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> * ''[[The Glass Menagerie (1987 film)|The Glass Menagerie]]'' (1987), released four years after [[Tennessee Williams]]' choking death. * ''[[Mr. North]]'' (1988), released a year after [[John Huston]]'s death. * ''[[Kansas (film)|Kansas]]'' (1988), ''[[War Party (1988 film)|War Party]]'' (1988) and ''[[Night Game (film)|Night Game]]'' (1989), all released following Spencer Eastman's death from [[lung cancer]]. * ''[[Always (1989 film)|Always]]'' (1989), released over four years after [[Diane Thomas]]'s death in a [[car accident]]; [[Jerry Belson]] completed the script after her death. * ''[[She's So Lovely]]'' (1997), released eight years after the death of [[John Cassavetes]] who wrote the script in 1987. * ''[[I Woke Up Early The Day I Died]]'' (1999), released twenty years after [[Ed Wood|Edward D. Wood, Jr.]]'s death from a heart attack. * ''[[After the Rain (film)|After the Rain]]'' (1999), exactly a year after [[Akira Kurosawa]]'s death from a [[stroke]]. * ''[[The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas]]'' (2000) and ''[[Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid]]'' (2004), both released after [[Jim Cash]]'s death. * ''[[One Night at McCool's]]'' (2001), released over nine months after Stan Seidel's death from [[Crohn's disease]]. * ''[[Heaven (2002 film)|Heaven]]'' (2002), ''[[Hell (2005 film)|Hell]]'' (2005), and ''[[Krzysztof Kieślowski#Legacy|Purgatory]]'' (2007), all following the death of [[Krzysztof Kieślowski]] in 1996. * ''[[The Singing Detective (film)|The Singing Detective]]'' (2003), released nine years after [[Dennis Potter]]'s death.<ref>{{cite web|last=Scott|first=A.O.|title=FILM REVIEW; A Pulp Novelist's Dreams Invade a Distressing Reality|date=24 October 2003|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=980DE3DA1431F937A15753C1A9659C8B63|accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> *''[[The Lost City (2005 film)|The Lost City]]'' (2005), released seven months after [[Guillermo Cabrera Infante]]'s death from septicemia. * ''[[Cars (film)|Cars]]'' (2006) and ''[[Mater and the Ghostlight]]'' (2006), both released a year after [[Joe Ranft]]'s death in a car accident. * ''[[The Contract (2006 film)|The Contract]]'' (2006), released a year after [[Stephen Katz (writer)|Stephen Katz]]'s death from prostate cancer. * ''[[Serious Moonlight (2009 film)|Serious Moonlight]]'' (2009), over three years after [[Adrienne Shelly]]'s murder. * ''[[Nine (2009 live-action film)|Nine]]'' (2009), over a year after co-writer [[Anthony Minghella]]'s death from a cancer-related [[hemorrhage]]. In addition, Minghella also wrote a segment in ''[[New York, I Love You]]'' (2008). * ''[[Main Street (2010 film)|Main Street]]'' (2010), released a year after [[Horton Foote]]'s death. * ''[[Justice League: Doom]]'' (2012; direct-to-video), released a year after [[Dwayne McDuffie]]'s death due to complications during heart surgery. * ''[[Tom and Jerry: Robin Hood and His Merry Mouse]]'' (2012; direct-to-video), released a year after [[Earl Kress]]' death from liver cancer. * ''[[Thor: The Dark World]]'' (2013), released seven months after writer [[Don Payne (writer)|Don Payne]]'s death from bone cancer. * ''[[Rio 2]]'' (2014), released over a year after [[Don Rhymer]]'s death from head and neck cancer in 2012. * ''[[The BFG (2016 film)|The BFG]]'' (2016), released seven months after [[Melissa Mathison]]'s death from neuroendocrine cancer. * ''[[Fences (film)|Fences]]'' (2016), released eleven years after [[August Wilson]]'s death from liver cancer; [[Tony Kushner]] built upon a draft of Wilson's for the final screenplay. * ''[[Cars 3]]'' (2017), released a year after [[Dan Gerson]]'s death from brain cancer. * ''[[The Other Side of the Wind]]'' (2018), released thirty-three years after [[Orson Welles]]' death.
==Producers== * ''[[The Million Dollar Mystery#Sequel and remake|Zudora]]'' (1914-1915), a 20-part serial whose first installment was released just over three months after producer [[Charles J. Hite]]'s death in an automobile accident; Hite was on the way to his home in [[New Rochelle, New York]], and was crossing the viaduct at 155th Street in [[Manhattan]] when his vehicle skidded off the roadway and onto the sidewalk, tore through an iron railing and plunged fifty feet before landing atop a wooden fence, with Hite underneath it, having suffered a fractured skull, a compound fracture to his jaw, and three broken ribs. After it took fifteen minutes to pull him from beneath it, Hite was taken to the hospital, where he died that same night. Both the serial's production and the film studio Hite owned, [[Thanhouser Company|Thanhouser]], went into a long, slow decline following his death. * ''[[The Viking (1931 film)|The Viking]]'' (1931), given its public release over three months after producer [[Varick Frissell]]'s death in an explosion, along with 26 other crew members, on board the [[SS Viking|SS ''Viking'']]; the film, shot on location in [[Newfoundland]] by co-directors [[George Melford]] and Frissell (Melford filming actors, Frissell filming nature) in the winter of 1930-31, had been nominally complete when Frissell screened it privately at the [[Nickel Theatre]] at [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]] on March 5, 1931, but the producer came away feeling it needed more sensational and realistic footage from the [[Labrador]] ice floes. Within days, Frissell and his crew re-joined the SS ''Viking'' (already used in the film) for its annual seal hunt to shoot more footage; however, the ship quickly became trapped in ice about {{convert|8|mi|km|spell=in}} off the [[Horse Islands (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Horse Islands]].
